questions.text: A 26/M presented with progressive dyspnea on exertion for 5 months. He is a stone crusher. He had a long‐standing cough with whitish sputum production, but denied fever, chills, weight loss, night sweats, and other symptoms. The patient undergoes bronchoscopy with bronchoalveolar lavage. The effluent appears milky. The cytopathology shows amorphous debris with periodic acid-Schiff (PAS)–positive macrophages. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Pulmonary alveolar proteinosis
- Abnormal accumulation of pulmonary surfactants in the alveolar space
- MC: Primary form: anti‐GM‐CSF antibody production
- Secondary form: Silicosis, Hematological malignancies

questions.text: A 58/M with a smoking history of 30 pack-years present to the emergency department after an episode of acute chest pain and shortness of breath. On physical examination, there is marked reduction of the breath sounds in the left hemithorax and tympanic note on percussion. What is the diagnosis?

Clinical findings of contralateral tracheal shift with absent breath sounds and hyper resonant note are suggestive of pneumothorax.

questions.text: A young man with tuberculosis presents with massive recurrent hemoptysis. For angiographic treatment, vascular structure to be evaluated first is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

bronchial artery.  Hemoptysis in these conditions originates from the bronchial circulation that is supplied by the aorta or intercostal arteries, not the pulmonary artery. Because of the high pressures, bleeding may be sudden and massive. Embolization of bronchial arteries feeding the suspected area may stop the bleeding.

choices.text: Posterior segment of right upper lobe

questions.text: A bed-ridden patient on a liquid diet develops aspiration pneumonia resulting in lung abscess. Which of the following is bronchopulmonary segment is most likely affected
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Posterior segment of right upper lobes 
In primary lung abscesses, the dependent segments (posterior upper lobes and superior lower lobes) are the most common locations, given the predisposition of aspirated materials to be deposited in these areas. Generally, the right lung is affected more commonly than the left because the right mainstem bronchus is less angulated

questions.text: DLCO is decreased in all except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Alveolar hemorrhage
DLCO can be increased in Polycythemia, alveolar hemorrhage and asthma

questions.text: A 65/M, chronic smoker is evaluated or progressive dyspnea with a low-pitched inspiratory and expiratory wheeze. His medical history is significant for an episode of necrotizing pancreatitis that resulted in ARDS and mechanical ventilation for 6 weeks prior to his recovery The flow volume curve is shown in Figure . What is the most likely cause of the patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Subglottic stenosis
Flow-volume loops are derived from spirometry. Following a maximum inspiratory effort from
residual volume, an individual forces the maximum volume of air from their lungs, and the resultant flows are plotted against the volume.
By convention, inspiration is shown on the lower portion of the curve and expiration is on the top.
A fixed central airflow obstruction results in flattening of the flow-volume loop in both inspiration and expiration, yielding the characteristic box-like effect, as in the given question. Examples of fixed airflow obstruction include tracheal stenosis and an obstructing central airway tumor.

questions.text: A 74-year-old man is evaluated for a 5-year history of gradually progressive dyspnea and dry cough without wheezing or hemoptysis. For the past 2 years he has had pain and occasional swelling in both knees. He has not had a fever or lost weight. He smoked one pack of cigarettes a day from the age of 18 to 60 years. He worked as a roofer for 40 years. Physical examination shows no digital clubbing or cyanosis. Auscultation of the lungs reveals bilateral end-inspiratory crackles. Pulmonary function testing shows:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Asbestosis
 Patients have history of asbestos exposure (roofer by occupation). Clinical examination is suggestive of ILD. Spirometry reveals a restrictive pattern with decreased FVC, RV, TLC and DLCO but preserved FeV1/FVC ratio. By this diagnosis of asbestosis can be made in the given patient

questions.text: A 29-year-old female presents with fatigue and exercise intolerance for 4 months, her FVC is 90%, FEV1/FVC IS 76%, SpO2 after 6-minute walk test was observed to drop from 90 to 86%. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

6-minute walk test showing more than 3% reduction SpO2 is considered as a marker of hypoxemia. The FVC is normal with a normal FEV1/FVC ratio excluding both obstructive and restrictive lung disease. The third mechanism for hypoxemia is an isolated defect of diffusion as seen in Pulmonary hypertension.
Pulmonary hypertension is most common among young females and in early stages comes with vague symptoms as fatigue and poor effort tolerance.

questions.text: All the following are typically characterized as an obstructive lung disease EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
Myasthenia gravis
Obstructive lung diseases are characterized by a reduction in the forced expiratory volume in 1 second (FEV1)/forced vital capacity (FVC) ratio, typically below 0.70. The typical lung diseases that manifest with airways obstruction include chronic obstructive lung disease (which includes emphysema and chronic bronchitis), asthma, bronchiectasis, and bronchiolitis.  Myasthenia gravis is a extrinsic restrictive lung disease and typically manifests with a restrictive ventilatory defect

questions.text: A 30-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance as his family found him unresponsive at home. He has a history of intravenous drug abuse and human immune deficiency virus (HIV) with medical noncompliance. His last CD4 count was <200/µL. On initial evaluation, his BP 120/75 mmHg, Pulse 105 bpm, respiratory rate 8/min, ABG on room air reveals pH:  7.16, PaCO2 :  70 mmHg & PaO2 : 55 mmHg. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Narcotic overdose   
H/O and ABG is suggestive of TYPE II respiratory failure and this might be caused due to IV narcotic overdose

questions.text: All the following are true about respiratory failure in ILD except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Normal A-a gradient                                                                                                                                                                                    
Type 1 respiratory failure is characterized by hypoxemia, normal to decreased CO2 levels and increased alveolar arterial gradient seen usually in pneumonia , ARDS and ILD.

questions.text: In ARDS not true is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Increased Pulmonary capillary wedge pressure 
ARDS is a clinical trial of hypoxemia, diffuse lung infiltrates, and reduced lung compliance not
attributable to congestive cardiac failure. This noncardiogenic pulmonary edema is identical to
congestive cardiac pulmonary edema in its effect on the mechanical properties of the lung and on gas exchange. Just as in cardiac pulmonary edema, the increase in lung water associated with ARDS produces interstitial edema and alveolar collapse, and so the affected lung becomes stiff and the alveolar-arterial oxygen tension difference widens.
-Unlike cardiac edema, however, the increase in lung water in ARDS occurs as a result of an increase in alveolar capillary permeability and is not due to an increase in hydrostatic forces.
-In clinical practice, determination of pulmonary artery wedge pressure is the most helpful
discriminant between ARDS and cardiac failure

questions.text: A 30-year-old presented with features of acute pancreatitis. A few days later he developed dyspnea. His chest Xray is shown below. The probable respiratory failure is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Type 1
H/O is suggestive of ARDS developing after Pancreatitis
TYPE I: ACUTE HYPOXEMIC RESPIRATORY FAILURE
This type of respiratory failure occurs with alveolar flooding and subsequent intrapulmonary shunt physiology. Seen in pneumonia, ILD, pulmonary edema (cardiogenic or noncardiogenic), and alveolar hemorrhage.
TYPE II RESPIRATORY FAILURE: HYPERCAPNIC RESPIRATORY FAILURE
This type of respiratory failure is a consequence of alveolar hypoventilation and results from the
inability to eliminate carbon dioxide effectively. Seen in neuromuscular diseases (e.g., myasthenia gravis), disease processes causing diminished respiratory drive (e.g., drug overdose, brainstem injury), and respiratory diseases associated with respiratory muscle fatigue (e.g., exacerbations of asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease [COPD]).
TYPE III RESPIRATORY FAILURE
This form of respiratory failure results from lung atelectasis. Because atelectasis occurs so commonly in the perioperative period, this form is also called perioperative respiratory failure
TYPE IV RESPIRATORY FAILURE
This form results from hypoperfusion of respiratory muscles in patients in shock

A nearly normal chest x-ray often occurs in PE.

questions.text: All are true for Pulmonary Embolism except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Westermark’s sign is dilated pulmonary artery

A normal or nearly normal chest x-ray often occurs in PE. Well-established abnormalities include focal oligemia (Westermark’s sign), a peripheral wedged-shaped density usually located at the pleural base (Hampton’s hump), and an enlarged right descending pulmonary artery (Palla’s sign).

choices.text: Continue IV fluids at 500 mL/hr. for a total of 4 L of fluid resuscitation and refer to surgical embolectomy.
Refer for inferior vena cava filter placement and continue current management.
Treat with dopamine and recombinant tissue plasminogen activator, 100 mg IV

questions.text: A 75 /M admitted in ICU for 5 days developed sudden onset dyspnea with chest pain. D dimer is positive.  CT angiography shows pulmonary artery thrombus. BP is 70/50 mmHg. Anticoagulation with unfractionated heparin is administered. After a fluid bolus of 1 L, the patient’s blood pressure remains low at 88/50 mmHg. The echocardiogram demonstrates hypokinesis of the right ventricle. On 100% non-rebreather mask, the SaO2 is 92%. What is the next best step in management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
Treat with dopamine and recombinant tissue plasminogen activator, 100 mg IV
Patient is presenting with massive pulmonary embolism plus with ongoing hypotension, right
ventricular dysfunction, and hypoxemia requiring 100% oxygen.
- In this setting, continuing with anticoagulation alone is inadequate, and the patient should receive circulatory support with fibrinolysis, if there are no contraindications.
-The recommended fibrinolytic regimen is recombinant tissue plasminogen activator (rTPA). Heparin should be continued with the fibrinolytic to prevent a rebound hypercoagulable state with dissolution of the clot.
-The only indication approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration for fibrinolysis in pulmonary embolus (PE) is for massive PE .
-In addition to fibrinolysis, the patient should also receive circulatory support with vasopressors.
- Caution should be taken with ongoing high-volume fluid administration as a poorly functioning
right ventricle may be poorly tolerant of additional fluids.
-If the patient had contraindications to fibrinolysis and was unable to be stabilized with vasopressor support, referral for surgical embolectomy should be considered. Referral for inferior vena cava filter placement is not indicated at this time. The patient should be stabilized hemodynamically as a first priority.

choices.text: Increased total lung capacity (TLC), decreased vital capacity (VC), decreased FEV1/FVC ratio
Decreased TLC, decreased VC, decreased residual volume (RV), increased FEV1/FVC ratio,
Decreased TLC, increased RV, normal FEV1/FVC ratio, decreased DLCO
Normal TLC, normal RV, normal FEV1/FVC ratio, decreased DLCO

questions.text: Match the pulmonary function test results to Idiopathic Pulmonary hypertension which it is most likely to be found.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Normal TLC, normal RV, normal FEV1/FVC ratio, decreased DLCO
Ventilatory function can be easily measured with lung volume measurement and the FEV1/FVC ratio. A
decreased FEV1/FVC ratio is characteristic of obstructive lung diseases. Alternatively, low lung volumes, specifically decreased total lung capacity (TLC), and occasionally decreased residual volume (RV) are characteristic of restrictive lung diseases. In Pulmonary Hypertension spirometry parameters can be normal but DLCO is decreased.

questions.text: Most common cause of Pulmonary Hypertension

WHO Group II

Outpatient treatment for CAP in patients with comorbidities is either Beta Lactam + Macrolide or Fluoroquinolone

questions.text: A 68/M presented with shortness of breath, fever, chills and cough with purulent sputum production for the last 2 days. He is conscious coherent, BP :105/70 mmHg, Pulse: 110 beats per min, breathing rate 32 breaths per min, and temperature 38.9 °C. Bronchial breath sounds are heard on auscultation of the right chest. Blood tests show elevated WBC count , urea 9 mMol/L, creatinine 1.6 mg% sodium 142 mmol/l and oxygen saturation (room air) 92%. Admit to hospital, start empirical antibiotic therapy within 4 h of admission

choices.text: The posterior upper lobes and superior lower lobes of right lungs are the most common locations of primary lung abscesses.
For primary lung abscess, the recommended treatment is with clindamycin
Primary lung abscesses are most common in ~80% of cases
Secondary lung abscesses usually arise from aspiration

questions.text: Regarding Lung abscess all are true except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Secondary lung abscesses usually arise from aspiration
- Primary lung abscesses are most common.  The dependent segments (posterior upper lobes and superior lower lobes of right lung) are the most common locations of primary lung abscesses.   The microbiology of primary lung abscesses often primarily including anaerobic organisms. For primary lung abscesses, the recommended treatment is with clindamycin
- Secondary lung abscesses rarely arise from aspiration. Secondary lung abscesses arise in the setting of an underlying condition, such as a post-obstructive process (e.g., a bronchial foreign body or tumor). In secondary lung abscesses, antibiotic coverage should be directed at the identified pathogen, and a prolonged course (until resolution of the abscess is documented) is often required.

questions.text: The most common causative organism for lobar pneumonia is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Streptococcus pneumoniae
The most common organisms which cause lobar pneumonia are Streptococcus pneumoniae, also called pneumococcus.
 MC of atypical pneumonia: Mycoplasma
•  MC nosocomial pneumonia: gram negative bacilli 
• MC early VAP: Streptococcus 
• MC late VAP: pseudomonas 
• MC VAP: pseudomonas 
• MC pneumonia in cystic fibrosis: pseudomonas 
• MC pneumonia resulting in ICU admission: streptococcus 
• MCC pneumonia in HIV: tuberculosis
• MC pneumonia in smokers: Strep. pneumonia
• MC trigger for asthma exacerbation: Rhinovirus
• MC cause exacerbation of COPD: H. influenza

questions.text: 60 Y/M, Diabetic and chronic alcoholic was admitted to the hospital with a fever, cough with red currant jelly sputum. Chest radiography reveals Right sided opacity. Which of the following organism can produce the below feature?

Klebsiella pneumoniae
CXR PA shows classical Right upper lobe consolidation with bulging fissure sign associated with pneumonia due to klebsiella.

questions.text: All following features are seen in the viral pneumonia except :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Predominance of alveolar exudates
Atypical pneumonia
§ Acute viral pneumonias or interstitial pneumonias are sometimes called atypical pneumonias because the typical features of air space pneumonia are not present in them.
The term ‘atypical” denotes
§ Less amount of sputum.
§ Only moderate elevation of white cell count.
§ No physical findings of consolidation
§ Lack of alveolar exudates.
§ Acute interstitial pneumonias result from infection by agents that are predominantly obligate intracellular pathogens.
§ Infections with these organisms evokes an acute inflammation that is usually restricted to the Interstitium without involvement of the alveolar spaces.

The most common cause of an exudative pleural effusion

questions.text: A 40-year-old man is evaluated for shortness of breath and left-sided chest discomfort without cough, fever, or hemoptysis. He had a contusion to the left side of his chest and back 3 weeks ago in an automobile accident. The patient has a history of lymphoma. Thoracentesis yields 500 mL of pleural fluid, and analysis shows: Total protein 3.5 g/dL , LDH 250 U/L , Amylase 25 U/L  Triglycerides 145 mg/dL , Cholesterol 38 mg/dL  Cytology, Gram stain, acid-fast bacilli stain, and bacterial culture are negative. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

questions.text: A 64/M requires endotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation for COPD. You are called acutely to the bedside when his BP abruptly drops to 70/40 mmHg. You notice high peak inspiratory pressures alarm on the ventilator. Breath sounds are inaudible on the right side and clear on the left. What is the best course of action currently?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Place a large-bore needle into the right second anterior intercostal space to alleviate a tension pneumothorax. Patients are on ventilator with sudden hypotension, increased peak inspiratory pressures, absent breath sounds is suggestive of tension pneumothorax. Immediately a large-bore needle is to be inserted into the second anterior intercostal space on the affected side to alleviate a tension pneumothorax

Pressure in the pleural space is positive throughout the respiratory cycle.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male smoker with a smoking history of 50 pack-years presents to the emergency department after an episode of acute chest pain and shortness of breath and low BP. On physical examination, there is marked reduction of the breath sounds in the left hemithorax with hyper resonant note. The following are true about this patient except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Shift of the mediastinum to the ipsilateral side of disease
Features of tension pneumothorax :
• Tension pneumothorax is a medical emergency
• Hyperresonance to percussion, and shift of the mediastinum to the opposite side
• Pressure in the pleural space is positive throughout the respiratory cycle.                         
• Decreased venous return to the heart and reduced cardiac output.    
• High peak inspiratory pressures during mechanical ventilation strongly suggest the diagnosis

Decline in PaCO2 levels

questions.text: Bronchial thermoplasty is approved in treatment of
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Asthma 

Bronchial thermoplasty is a bronchoscopy treatment using thermal energy to ablate airway smooth muscle in accessible bronchi. It may reduce exacerbation and improve asthma control in highly selected patients not controlled on maximal inhaler therapy.

questions.text: In a patient with COPD, the most accurate method for measuring lung volumes is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Body plethysmography. 
Spirometry does not measure total lung capacity because it cannot account for residual volume. The most frequently used and accurate measures of lung volumes are steady-state helium dilution lung volumes and body plethysmography.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

It has a mechanism of bronchodilation 

Ensifentrine is a first-in-class inhaled dual PDE3 and PDE4 inhibitor.
PDE3 inhibition → smooth muscle relaxation → bronchodilation
PDE4 inhibition → reduces inflammation → anti-inflammatory effect
It improves symptoms (like dyspnea) in select cases of COPD (not in acute exacerbations)

questions.solution:

Pseudomonas aeruginosa followed by Staph.

questions.text: Bronchiectasis more pronounced in mid lung fields is commonly seen in
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Mycobacterium avium infection
Bronchiectasis, the more pronounced involvement of the upper lung fields is most
common in cystic fibrosis (CF) and  post radiation fibrosis.                                                                                                                                 Bronchiectasis with predominant involvement of the lower lung fields usually has its source in chronic recurrent aspiration, end stage fibrotic lung disease (e.g., traction bronchiectasis from idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis), or recurrent immunodeficiency-associated infections (e.g., hypogammaglobulinemia).                                                                                                                                                Bronchiectasis resulting from infection by nontuberculous mycobacteria (NTM), most commonly the Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare complex (MAC), often preferentially affects the midlung fields.

questions.text: In a patient with hypoxemia, which of the following arterial blood gas (ABG) findings would you expect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 PaO2 60 mmHg, SaO2 88%
Explanation: In hypoxemia, the PaO2 is typically lower than normal (less than 80 mmHg), and the oxygen saturation (SaO2) is also reduced (less than 90%).

questions.text: Which is the extra-pulmonary cause of hypoxemia with increased A-a gradient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 Intracardiac shunts
Increased (A-a) gradient indicated pulmonary defect of diffusion due to shunt formation. The common causes are Pulmonary edema, Pneumonia, ARDS. The only extrapulmonary cause is Intracardiac shunts.

choices.text: Fatigue can be an early symptom
Pulmonary hypertension is a dreaded complication
Pulmonary hypertension reverses with treatment of the cause

questions.text: The following statements about Chronic Hypoxemia are true EXCEPT
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Pulmonary hypertension reverses with treatment of the cause
Pulmonary Hypertension is an irreversible complication of Chronic hypoxemia due to pulmonary vasoconstriction. It causes death due to heart failure and hence dreaded. COPD is a common cause. Once Pulmonary hypertension is established, the only treatment to prolong long term survival is Home Oxygen therapy.

questions.text: A patient presents with acute hyperventilation. Which of the following ABG findings is most likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

pH 7.50, PaCO2 30 mmHg, HCO3- 24 mEq/L
Explanation: Acute hyperventilation leads to respiratory alkalosis, characterized by an elevated pH and decreased PaCO2. The bicarbonate (HCO3-) level remains normal in the acute phase.

questions.text: A patient with hyperventilation presents with tingling in the extremities and carpopedal spasm. What is the underlying mechanism for these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Hypocalcemia
Explanation: Hyperventilation causes a decrease in PaCO2, leading to respiratory alkalosis. This alkalosis increases the binding of calcium to albumin, reducing ionized calcium levels and causing symptoms of hypocalcemia, such as tingling and carpopedal spasm.

questions.text: A patient with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) has the following ABG results: pH 7.36, PaCO2 55 mmHg, PaO2 65 mmHg, HCO3- 30 mEq/L. What does this indicate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Compensated respiratory acidosis
Explanation: The ABG results show a normal pH with elevated PaCO2 and HCO3-. This indicates compensated respiratory acidosis, where the kidneys have increased bicarbonate to compensate for the chronic elevation in PaCO2.

questions.text: Which ABG result is most indicative of a mixed respiratory and metabolic acidosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

pH 7.25, PaCO2 60 mmHg, HCO3- 18 mEq/L
Explanation: The ABG results show acidemia (low pH) with both elevated PaCO2 (respiratory acidosis) and decreased HCO3- (metabolic acidosis), indicating a mixed disorder.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is most likely to cause a mixed metabolic acidosis and respiratory alkalosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Salicylate poisoning
Explanation: Salicylate poisoning can cause a mixed acid-base disorder with metabolic acidosis due to increased production of organic acids and respiratory alkalosis due to direct stimulation of the respiratory center.

questions.text:

2. Respiratory Alkalosis is most common defect in Pregnancy
3. Both Metabolic Acidosis and Alkalosis can co-exist

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is most likely to cause a high anion gap metabolic acidosis?
questions.solution:

Methanol poisoning
Explanation: High anion gap metabolic acidosis is often caused by conditions that increase the production of organic acids, such as methanol poisoning, diabetic ketoacidosis, and lactic acidosis.

questions.text: A young boy presents with short stature to the clinic. USG reveals Nephrocalcinosis. ABG reveals Metabolic Acidosis with Urine ph of 7. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

 Type 1 RTA
Type 1/Distal RTA is an inherited defect of H-K-ATPase pump in the collecting ducts causing severe acidemia with Uph>5.5. The Acidemia causes short stature and hypercalciuria is associated with Nephrocalcinosis.

questions.text: Fanconi’s syndrome consists of following EXCEPT
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Calciuria
Fanconi’s syndrome is associated with Type 2/Proximal RTA. The triad of Glycosuria, Aminoaciduria and phosphaturia are due to nutrient reabsorption defect in the PCT.

questions.text: Following drugs can cause Hyperkalemic RTA EXCEPT
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Amphotericin B
Amphotericin B can cause Type 1 RTA.

choices.text: It is an Autosomal Recessive defect of ENaC
Hypotension is a common finding in majority
Amiloride is the treatment of choice

questions.text: Following statements about Liddle’s syndrome are False EXCEPT
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Elevated Serum Aldosterone levels
Liddle’s syndrome is an AR stimulatory ENaC defect which mimics Aldosterone-excess state causing Hypertension and edema. However, there is a suppression of RAAS and unmeasurable Serum Aldosterone levels. The disease is also called Pseudo-Hyper-Aldosteronism. Amiloride is the drug of choice.

questions.text: A young boy presented with paralytic ileus. BP-80/60mm of Hg. Laboratory tests reveals Hypokalemia, Hypomagnesemia with Elevated Plasma HCO3 and Elevated Serum Renin levels. The probable diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Gitelman’s syndrome
Gitelman’s syndrome is an AR Inhibitory defect of Na-Cl co-transporter leading to diuresis and dehydration. There is secondary hyper-aldosteronism leading to hypokalemic alkalosis. There is associated paracellular transport defect of Magnesium causing Hypomagnesemia responsible for Ileus and risk of arrythmias.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents with recurrent kidney stones, metabolic acidosis, and normal anion gap. Which type of Renal Tubular Acidosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Type I (Distal RTA) Explanation: Distal RTA often leads to recurrent kidney stones due to the inability to acidify urine, resulting in calcium phosphate precipitation. The normal anion gap distinguishes RTA from other forms of metabolic acidosis.

questions.text: All the following features can be used to differentiate Bartter’s and Gitelman’s syndrome EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Hypotension

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents to an ENT clinic with sensorineural deafness. He has no history of ear infection or any illicit drug use in the past. Systemic examination reveals normal Blood pressure. He complains of recurrent loin pain in the past with hematuria. His renal function test reveals elevated Creatinine and urine examination revealed eumorphic RBC’s. other systemic examination is normal. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Barrter’s syndrome

Barrter’s syndrome is an autosomal recessive inherited channelopathy of the renal tubules causing inhibition of the Na-K-2Cl ATPase pump. This leads to dehydration and can cause renal dysfunction due to tubular defect. It is associated with increased risk of renal calculi due to hypercalciuria. The same pump maintains endolymph concentration in the cochlea and leads to sensorineural deafness.
Renal dysfunction with deafness in a young male can mimic Alport’s syndrome. But Alport’s syndrome causes recurrent hematuria (dysmorphic) due to glomerulonephritis and associated with Lens defect.

questions.text: Which is the first line treatment in a case of prerenal AKI?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Fluid challenge
Explanation: Prerenal AKI is often caused by conditions that reduce blood flow to the kidneys, such as hypovolemia (low blood volume) due to dehydration, blood loss, or severe heart failure, septic shock and rarely due to drugs disrupting autoregulation. Hence, the first line treatment is fluid challenge with Isotonic fluid like Normal saline.

questions.text: Which diagnostic test is most useful in differentiating between prerenal and intrinsic renal causes of AKI?

questions.text: A 27-year-old man with known ulcerative colitis is admitted to hospital for management of an acute severe flare in colitis. His stool frequency is 10 times per day including nocturnal bowel opening, and he has a mild fever. Blood pressure is 122/78 mmHg, pulse is 88 beats/min; CRP is 82 mg/L. What is the most appropriate initial management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Intravenous glucocorticoid therapy is indicated in this case of acute severe ulcerative colitis (> 6 bloody stools/24 hrs., raised CRP). Current guidelines suggest reviewing on day 3 and then day 5 for clinical and biochemical response. If non-response, rescue medical therapies with anti-TNF biological therapy or cyclosporin can be considered. Alternatively, non-response to intravenous (IV) steroid therapy and rescue medical therapies require a surgical review for consideration of subtotal colectomy and ileostomy. There is no evidence for antibiotic therapy. Vedolizumab (anti-α4β7 integrin biological therapy) can be considered for maintenance treatment of IBD; it has a long onset of action and therefore has no role in the management of acute severe colitis.

questions.text: A 54-year-old man with ulcerative colitis is receiving hospital treatment for acute severe ulcerative colitis. He becomes acutely unwell with sweating and shortness of breath.  Pulse is 110 beats/min, blood pressure is 120/68 mmHg, temperature is 37.7°C and respiratory rate is 28 breaths/min. Oxygen saturation is 84% on air. What is the most appropriate investigation to lead to the diagnosis?

A complication of acute severe IBD is thrombosis. This presentation and clinical status suggest a pulmonary embolus and therefore CTPA is most likely to lead to the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 28‐year‐old woman is presented with abdominal pain for more than 6 months the frequency of which has increased to 1 day per week for last 3months and pain is associated with defecation. There is a hardening of stools since her symptoms have started, there is no blood in the stools. There is no fever, nocturnal diarrhea or weight loss. The most likely diagnosis in this patient is:

Rome IV criteria for the diagnosis of irritable bowel syndrome: abdominal pain on average at least 1 day per week during the previous 3 months that is associated with two or more of the following-
• Related to defecation 
• Associated with a change in stool frequency
• Associated with a change in stool consistency

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with jaundice, pale stools and pruritus. Blood tests show serum total bilirubin 7 mg/dL(elevated), ALT 40 U/L(normal) and serum ALP 580 U/L(elevated). What would be your next line investigation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The patient presents with painful obstructive jaundice. The blood tests represent a typical cholestatic picture with elevated ALP and GGT, making viral hepatitis unlikely. In this setting, ultrasound would be the first-line investigation to seek evidence of biliary obstruction with dilated common bile duct due to, for example, gallstone disease. Pancreatic cancer is more classically associated with painless obstructive jaundice.

questions.text: An 18-year-old medical student has hepatitis B and C status checked as part of his occupational health screening for entrance to medical school. His results are as follows: LFTs: Bilirubin 0.70 mg/dL, ALT 19 U/L HCV antibody not detected, Hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) positive, Antibody to HBsAg (anti-HBs) negative, Antibody to hepatitis B core antigen (anti-HBc) IgM negative, Anti-HBc IgG positive. What is the next step in his management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

This medical student has chronic hepatitis B. Hepatitis B surface antigen is the hallmark of chronic HBV infection if present for more than 6 months. This patient is unlikely to have acute infection with normal transaminases and negative anti-HBc IgM. questions.text: A Which of the following statements is true about the hepatitis D virus?
questions.solution:

HDV is an RNA-defective virus that requires the simultaneous presence of HBV for replication and has the same sources and modes of spread. HBV replication is usually suppressed by HDV. Liver damage is believed to be due to HDV and persistent HDV replication in co-infected patients leads to higher annual rates of cirrhosis and HCC. Interferon-alfa is the only effective drug against HDV but the optimal duration of therapy is not well defined.

questions.text: Which anti diabetes agents can be useful in hepatic encephalopathy

Acarbose, an intestinal α-glucosidase inhibitor used to treat type 2 diabetes mellitus, inhibits the intestinal absorption of carbohydrates and glucose and results in their enhanced delivery to the colon. As a result, the ratio of saccharolytic to proteolytic bacterial flora is increased, and blood ammonia levels are decreased

questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

This is a case of Acute Pericarditis and the most likely ECG change would be ST segment elevation concave upwards in all leads except aVR. T wave inversion occurs in these cases after 2 weeks when ST segment has returned to baseline.

choices.text: History of CVA with hemiparesis one month ago
Patient is on warfarin for AF with INR 1.8

questions.text: Which of the following is absolute contraindication to the use thrombolytic agent the setting of an acute anterior wall ‘myocardial infarction
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Absolute contraindications to the use of thrombolytic therapy in acute MI are – Past h/o hemorrhagic stroke anytime in life, past h/o ischemic stroke in last 1 year, suspected aortic dissection, active internal bleeding (except menses), BP>180/110mmHg.

questions.text: Atrial fibrillation may occur in all of the following conditions, except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 Atrial Fibrillation is most commonly caused by MV disease; other causes include CAD, Cardiomyopathies, Constrictive pericarditis, thyrotoxicosis, alcohol induced (holiday heart syndrome) & lone AF.

questions.text: A post-menopausal female presented with sudden onset angina. Coronary Angiography revealed normal vessels. Ventriculography performed in this patient during systole revealed the following picture. What is the probable diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Takotsubo cardiomyopathy – Stress induced cardiomyopathy (Broken Heart syndrome) is a unknown etiology transient myocardial ischemia syndrome common in postmenopausal females especially after intense emotional stimulus. Patients often present with chest pain, have ST-segment elevation on electrocardiography (ECG), and have elevated cardiac enzyme levels consistent with myocardial infarction (MI). However, when the patient undergoes cardiac angiography, left ventricular (LV) apical ballooning (as seen in the Question image – Takotsubo) is present, and there is no significant coronary artery stenosis. 
The prognosis in TCM is typically excellent, with nearly 95% of patients experiencing complete recovery within 4-8 weeks. Complications occur in 20% of TCM cases, particularly in the early stage.

questions.text: Unstable angina is characterized by all of the following features EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Elevated biomarkers indicate infarction. In the presence of ST-T changes on the ECG, positive biomarkers are indicative of NSTEMI. Unstable angina includes following:
1. all new onset angina (<2> = 3 episodes per day
4. Post-MI (up to 1 month)

questions.text: Pulsus Paradoxus is seen in all EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

AV dissociation causes Reverse Pulsus paradoxus. 
Pulsus paradoxus: exaggerated reduction in the strength of the arterial pulse during normal inspiration (N) is < 10 mm Hg systolic pressure. The causes include:
 * Pericardial tamponade  * Severe COPD/ Asthma
 * SVC obstruction    * Constrictive pericarditis (<1/3 pts)
 * Hypovolemic shock   * Pulmonary embolism

Reverse pulsus paradoxus: an inspiratory rise in arterial pressure.
 * HOCM, AV dissociation, IPPV

questions.text: Ventriculization of JVP is characteristic of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Severe Tricuspid Regurgitation.
In Severe TR, the atrial pressure during relaxation increases due to the regurgitant jet from the ventricle. This abolishes the ‘x’ descent and converts the JVP waveform into a ‘cv’ pattern. This simulates an arterial pulse waveform; hence, called as verticalization of JVP. (see below image)

questions.text: Cannon “a” wave on the JVP is characteristic of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 AV dissociation.

The positive presystolic a wave is produced by venous distention due to right atrial contraction and is the dominant wave in the JVP, particularly during inspiration. 
Large ‘a’ waves indicate that the right atrium is contracting against an increased resistance, such as occurs with tricuspid stenosis or more commonly with increased resistance to right ventricular filling (pulmonary hypertension or pulmonic stenosis). Large a waves also occur during arrhythmias whenever the right atrium contracts while the tricuspid valve is closed by right ventricular systole. 
“Cannon” a waves may occur regularly (as during junctional rhythm)or irregularly (as in atrioventricular dissociation with ventricular tachycardia or complete heart block). 
The a wave is absent in patients with atrial fibrillation, and there is an increased delay between the a wave and the carotid arterial pulse in patients with first-degree atrioventricular block.

questions.text: Loud S1 is seen in all EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 S1 is produced by the closure of the AV valves (mitral & Tricuspid).
Loud S1 - MS, TS, Tachycardia, short PR interval high output states.
Soft S1- MR, TR, obesity, prolonged PR interval, mitral valve calcification.
Variable S1- AF, Extra systole.

questions.text: Valsalva maneuver increases the murmur of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

HOCM

Respiration:
Right-sided murmurs generally increase with inspiration.
Left-sided murmurs usually are louder during expiration.

Valsalva maneuver:
Most murmurs decrease in length and intensity.
Two exceptions are:

The systolic murmur of HOCM (Hypertrophic Obstructive Cardiomyopathy), which becomes much louder.

The murmur of MVP (Mitral Valve Prolapse), which becomes longer and often louder.

After release of the Valsalva maneuver, right-sided murmurs tend to return to baseline intensity earlier than left-sided murmurs.

questions.text: A systolic murmur that becomes more prominent on standing is a feature of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)  
HOCM.   

Exercise:
Murmurs caused by blood flow across normal or obstructed valves (e.g., PS and MS) become louder with both isotonic and isometric (handgrip) exercise.
Murmurs of MR, VSD, and AR also increase with handgrip exercise.

Positional changes:

With standing, most murmurs diminish.
Two exceptions are:

HOCM murmur – becomes louder

MVP murmur – lengthens and is often intensified

With squatting, most murmurs become louder, but murmurs of HOCM and MVP usually soften and may disappear.

Passive leg raising usually produces the same effects as squatting.

questions.text: Atrial fibrillation leads to disappearance of following clinical sign/signs:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Atrial fibrillation causes ineffective atrial contraction.
a-wave on JVP is due to RA contraction
S4 is due to rapid blood flow into partially filled ventricle during atrial systole.
Presystolic accentuation is due to late ventricular filling due to atrial contraction.
In Atrial fibrillation, all above features are lost.

choices.text: Myxomatous degeneration affects posterior valve leaflet more commonly
MVP is the most common cause of isolated mitral regurgitation
Risk of IE is low when it is associated with Mitral regurgitation

questions.text: Following statements about Barlow’s syndrome are true except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Mitral Valve Prolapse/Barlow’s syndrome /Click murmur syndrome is a myxomatous degeneration of the cardiac valves. It predominantly affects the Mitral Valve (Posterior leaflet) and in 10-15% may affect the Tricuspid valve also. The degenerated MV becomes redundant and may allow a jet of MR. 
MVP is defined as bulge of the MV >=2 mm beyond the annulus of the mitral valve. Usually lesions between 2-5mm are symptomatic and unlikely to progress to MR and require no treatment. Lesions > 5mm valve thickness are classical. Patients having asymmetric thickening of the leaflets are likely to progress to MR and are associated with increased risk of IE requiring prophylaxis.

questions.text: 10 yr boy is admitted with infective endocarditis. On examination Gibson’s murmur is audible. Mother gives H/O Rubella infection during pregnancy. The most likely diagnosis in this case is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

PDA – is persistence of the ductus arteriosus beyond 1 month of age. It is seen more commonly in children born in high altitude, prematurity and maternal rubella. 
The ductus is kept patent by PG synthesis which is inhibited after birth due to increasing oxygenation in pulmonary vessels. It produces a Continuous murmur/Train in Tunnel murmur/ Gibson’s murmur which is best auscultated in the first ICS on left side (Gibson’s area). 
Common teratogenic conditions include:
1. Rubella- PDA, Pulmonary A Stenosis
2. Alcohol - VSD
3. Phenytoin- PS
4. Thalidomide- Phocomelia
5. Lithium - Ebstein anomaly

questions.text: 28-year gentleman was detected to have BP 150/96mm of hg on 2 different occasions. He is a non-smoker and has a BMI of 27. On examination: P=86/min regular with a Radio-Femoral delay. Auscultation revealed an ejection click in the aortic area with systolic thrill in supra-sternal notch. ECG show LVH. The specific treatment would be:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Patient has Co-arctation of Aorta. It is commonly associated with Bicuspid Aortic valve which is manifest as an ejection click in the given patient. Also few patients may have renal artery stenosis. However, the presence of Radio-femoral delay indicated coarctation which is best treated by aortoplasty. Delay in the treatment can lead to persistence of systemic hypertension and its related target organ damage.

questions.text: 44-year lady presents with c/o angina for the last month. There is H/o syncopal attack in the past year which were attributed to a low hemoglobin of 8.2gm/dl by the family doctor. On examination there is a low pulse pressure with a ejection systolic murmur radiating to the carotids. There is no H/O PND/orthopnea and chest auscultation Is unremarkable. Which of the drugs is contraindicated in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Aortic stenosis without evidence of failure. The patients LV function depends on adequate Pre-load. Hence, diuretic therapy in absence of congestive heart failure can decrease the Pre-load and precipitate sudden shock.

choices.text: Asymptomatic Complete Heart Block (Third degree AV bock)
Atrial fibrillation with conduction pause > 5 seconds

questions.text: Indications for permanent pacemaker implantation include all EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 Indications for permanent pacemaker implantation are :
1. Symptomatic AV block (Type2/3)
2. All cases of CHB
3. Symptomatic AV block due to use of essential drug
4. Alternating BBB
5. Atrial fibrillation with conduction pause > 5 seconds
6. Escape rhythm < 40>= 3 seconds
8. Post-operative or Catheter ablation procedure leading to AV block (remote chance of recovery)

questions.text: Match the following :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

choices.text: Diastolic Collapse of right ventricle on echocardiogram.

questions.text: Most specific sign in cardiac tamponade is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Diastolic Collapse of the RV on echocardiography is pathognomic of Cardiac Tamponade.

Cardiac Tamponade : is a medical emergency most commonly as a complication of pericardial effusion. Accumalation of fluid in the pericardium, resulting in impaired filling of the cardiac chambers and equalises the pressure in all chambers. It also impedes the venous return. 
Patient presents with “Beck’s triad”: Tachycardia, hypotension and muffled heart sounds. 
Pulsus Paradoxus and Kussmaul’s sign maybe present in both tamponade and constrictive
pericarditis. Hence differentiation is based on Echocardiography. The diastolic collapse of the RV to the increased pressure in the pericardial cavity is pathognomic of the disease.
Treatment is emergency therapeutic pericardiocentesis with a favourable prognosis. 
Tamponade not relieved  by pericardiocentesis is often lethal.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with rheumatic mitral stenosis with atrial fibrillation is on therapy for a fast-ventricular rate. While on treatment, he developed a regular pulse of 64/min. The most likely drug being administered was:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 Digoxin. The therapeutic options for atrial fibrillation can be broadly classified into Rate-control and Rhythm control drugs. Considering there is return to sinus rhythm in the given patient, it is concluded that patient is on rhythm control drugs viz. Digoxin and Amiodarone.

questions.text: All of the following heart sounds occur shortly after S2 except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Ejection click is the sound of Semilunar valve opening (Aortic and Pulmonary valves) This event occurs before S2.

questions.text: A 54year old male patient was brought to the emergency department with chest pain, perspiration. His BP-80/60mm of Hg. ECG was taken (see image). Which of the following is the most likely cause of shock?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

ECG shows IWMI with Right ventricular infarct.

questions.text: Which test is performed to detect reversible myocardial ischemia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Thallium Viability scan

questions.text: A 26-year-old man complains of abdominal distension. swelling of the legs and easy fatigability. His blood pressure is 70mm Hg and pulse becomes difficult to feel on inspiration. JVP is grossly elevated and rises further on deep inspiration. He has pedal edema, ascites and tender hepatomegaly. Precordium is quiet. The probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 Constrictive Pericarditis.
It is a chronic complication of pericarditis. In developing countries, it is a sequalae of TB pericarditis.
The symptoms are similar to cardiac tamponade and may offer diagnostic dilemma as both conditions may have Pulsus paradoxus and Kussmaul’s sign as mentioned in the question. But Tamponade is an acute complication and no tender hepatomegaly occurs.

questions.text: With complete bundle branch blocks the QRS interval is?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D)

choices.text: Seizures presenting as a status epilepticus
Seizures associated with Postictal Todd’s paralysis

questions.text: All of the following are risk factors associated with recurrent seizures EXCEPT
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Risk factors associated with recurrent seizures are
• Seizures presenting as a status epilepticus
• Seizures associated with Postictal Todd’s paralysis
• Strong family history of seizures
• An abnormal focal  neurologic examination
• An abnormal EEG

questions.text: A 47-year-old man was brought by his wife to casualty. He had been hallucinating that morning seeing three dogs running across his living floor and four small children in the kitchen. Such formed visual hallucinations may occur in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
 Temporal lobe pathology.
Visual hallucinations can occur with lesions anywhere within the visual system but formed visual hallucinations of people, animals and objects often occur with diseases affecting the temporal lobes or in diffuse Lewy body disease.
Occipital lobe epilepsy tends to cause unformed images that are usually patterns.
Migrainous aura has fortification spectra and lights that move across visual field.

choices.text: Jacksonian epilepsy is spreading seizure activity.
Serum level of prolactin increases dramatically after tonic clonic convulsions.
Changes in memory are not features of focal seizure with impaired awareness.
Absence seizures are briefer and more frequent without post ictal confusion .

questions.text: The following statement are true about epilepsy except :-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Changes in memory/perception and blackouts are not features of focal seizure with impaired awareness.
Complex partial seizure are characterized by focal seizure activity with transient unconsciousness beginning with an aura. Behavioural arrest or motionless stare denotes beginning of ictal phase which marks the onset of period of amnesia & automatisms. Following seizure anterograde amnesia ,confusion and post ictal aphasia is present.

questions.text: Ratio of drug concentration in breast milk relative to serum is minimal  with which of the following antiepileptic drug?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Valproate.
Antiepileptic medications are excreted into breast milk to a variable degree. The ratio of drug concentration in breast milk relative to serum ranges from 5% (valproic acid) to 300% (levetiracetam). Given the overall benefits of breast-feeding and the lack of evidence for long-term harm to the infant by being exposed to antiepileptic drugs, mothers with epilepsy can be encouraged to breast-feed. This should be reconsidered, however, if there is any evidence of drug effects on the infant such as lethargy or poor feeding.

choices.text: Ability to suppress seizure activity for more than 24 hours after one injection.
Rapid onset of action after intravenous administration.

questions.text: Most physicians recommend using high dose of intravenous benzodiazepine as part of management of status epilepticus because it has which of the following qualities?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Rapid onset of action after intravenous administration.
At one time the most popular benzodiazepine for use in status epilepticus was diazepam, which has rapid onset of action in the brain, but is distributed in the body relatively quickly. Because of this property, patients needed additional medication to protect themselves from recurrent seizure activity as early as 20 minutes after diazepam injection. A less fat soluble benzodiazepine, lorazepam, has advantage of acting rapidly but being cleared ore slowly from the brain.

questions.text:
In treatment of epilepsy, sodium valproate :-
1). Is the drug of choice in pregnant women.
2). Can cause weight loss.
3). No blood tests are required to screen for liver abnormalities.
4). Can cause hirsutism.
5). Is usually the drug of choice in primary generalized epilepsy.
Select the correct answer using the code given below:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 5 only. 
Sodium valproate has a high incidence of teratogenicity and should be avoided in women of child bearing age. A screen of LFT is requisite as valproate can be hepatotoxic. Weight gain is also a common problem with it. Phenytoin & carbamazepine can cause hirsutism but valproate causes hair loss. It is usually the drug of choice for primary generalized epilepsy.

questions.text: A 28-year-old female primigravida 2 months pregnant known case of JME off any AED presently presented with an episode of GTCS preceded by multiple episodes of myoclonus. Which of the following would be best to start her therapy ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

LEVETRIACETAM.
The drug of first choice in the treatment of JME is sodium valproate, which has a response rate of up to 80%. Valproate should be avoided in women of childbearing age because of significantly increased risks of fetal malformations and neurodevelopmental delay. Levetiracetam or lamotrigine are alternative first-line options if valproate is contraindicated.
There has been some studies suggesting lamotrigine could exacerbate myoclonus so Levetiracetam could be an ideal choice for the patient.

questions.text: Match the following Gait disorders
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

 I(II) II(I) III(IV).IV.(III)

questions.text: A 79 year old male presents to his doctor after his wife noticed that he had slowed down and his posture has changed in that he has bent over. The following would support a diagnosis of Parkinson disease:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Shuffling gait.
Spasticity is a feature of hypertonia associated with upper motor neuron lesions and is not a feature of PD. Rigidity ,either lead pipe or cogwheel ,is the form of hypertonia associated with PD. Supranuclear vertical gaze palsies in the context of parkinsonism tend to occur with progressive supranuclear palsy. The tremor is pill rolling rest tremor, not a postural tremors.

questions.text: Which of the following is most useful in the diagnosis of parkinsonism:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Diagnosis of PD is always made based on clinical symptoms coupled with a good clinical examination.

choices.text: A 64 year old woman on levodopa –carbidopa who continues to experience episode of freezing while walking.
A 68 year old man with recurrent falls due to orthostatic hypotension.
A 70 year old woman with severe tremor unresponsive to therapy.
A 71 year old man with worsening symptoms of dementia.

questions.text: Which of the following patients with Parkinson disease is the best candidate for deep brain stimulation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

A 70 year old woman with severe tremor unresponsive to therapy.
Most surgical procedures for PD performed today utilize deep brain stimulation (DBS). Here, an electrode is placed into the target area and connected to a stimulator inserted SC over the chest wall. DBS simulates the effects of a lesion without necessitating a brain lesion. 
The procedure is thus primarily indicated for patients who suffer disability resulting from levodopa-induced motor complications that cannot be satisfactorily controlled with drug manipulation. Another indication is intractable tremors not responding to anticholinergics.

choices.text: A cervical myelopathy secondary to cervical spondylosis.
A right middle cerebral artery ischemic stroke.

questions.text: Following clinical sign is unilateral in
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

A right middle cerebral artery ischemic stroke
Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis is associated with bilateral degeneration of both upper and lower motor neurons.Any cause of myelopathy will usually cause bilateral extensor plantar responses.Multiple sclerosis is associated with diffuse white matter involvement which often involves both corticospinal tracts at some point in their long pathway.

questions.text: A 67-year-old male presented with complaint of a fogging of vision in the left eye which he described as a “curtain doming down”. It lasted a minute before returning to normal. There were no other symptoms. The following is the most likely cause of his visual impairment.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Carotid embolism.
Amaurosis fugax is transient visual loss caused by a blockage of the ophthalmic artery or its branches to the retina. It can occur due to carotid embolism.
Retinitis pigmentosa causes progressive visual loss which usually starts in the peripheral visual field and spreads to involve central vision.
Papilledema due to raised intracranial pressure can also cause progressive visual loss starting at the periphery.

choices.text: Total left middle cerebral artery infarction.
Lacunar infarction of the internal capsule.
Partial left middle cerebral artery infarction.

questions.text: A 74-year-old hypertensive man developed an acute onset severe weakness in his right side involving his arm & leg. On examination, he has a right hemiplegia with no sensory loss. Which of the following lesion best explains his deficit:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Lacunar infarction of the internal capsule.
Pure motor loss is due to lacunar infarction of internal capsule due to infarction of lenticulostriate branches of MCA.
Due to partial or total MCA infarction sensory loss is seen with motor weakness.

choices.text: Total left middle cerebral artery infarction.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old woman was involved in a car accident and suffered a severe whiplash injury but was otherwise well. The following day she presents to casualty with weakness on her right side, confusion and incomprehensible speech. On examination she has a left sided Horner’s syndrome, right hemiplegia and right homonymous hemianopia. Unfortunately, she became drowsy and obtunded over the next 24 hours and dies. 
Which of the following lesion best explains her disorder:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 Internal carotid artery occlusion.
Complete carotid occlusion can be fatal due to post infarction edema. In this case left carotid artery dissection following a declaration car accident car accident and sympathetic fibers are involved due to carotid dissection.
Middle cerebral artery infarction would occur due to internal carotid occlusion but Horner’s syndrome will not happen due to MCA occlusion.
Internal capsule infarction will have motor symptoms only.
Cerebellar hemorrhage is post HTN bleed, will present predominantly with cerebellar symptoms.

questions.text: A 72 year old right handed man was admitted to the stroke unit.A CT brain scan performed identified an infarct in right middle cerebral artery  territory .The following signs typically occur with non dominant cortical lesions :-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Dressing apraxia.
The dominant cerebral cortex is on the left in the majority of right handed people is specifically involved in reading ,math(dyscalculia),writing and language. Apraxia’s involving visuospatial tasks like dressing and drawing shapes is a symptom of dysfunction in the non dominant lobe .More subtle functions of the dominant parietal lobe include naming fingers (If abnormal this is called a finger agnosia ) and left to right discrimination.

choices.text: Posterior communicating artery aneurysm with SAH
Anterior communicating Artery aneurysm with SAH

questions.text: A 46 yr old patient complaining of severe bursting headache on examination he was found to be conscious but restless, neck stiffness & drooping of right eyelid were observed. Clinical diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
3rd nerve palsy,posterior communicating artery & 3rd nerve are in close relation.
Headache suggest SAH

questions.text:
A 58-year-old woman develops acute onset weakness in the right side of her face & right arm with slurring of speech. She is assessed within 90 minutes of symptom onset and deemed a candidate for thrombolysis.
What is the single most appropriate next action?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

CT brain.
A CT scan of the brain is needed to exclude hemorrhagic stroke first, which would contraindicate thrombolysis. Alteplase therapy would follow if it is not a hemorrhagic stroke. MRI is not performed to rule out hemorrhagic stroke.

questions.text: A 75-year-old male presents with an acute stroke. On examination he has mild right arm and face weakness. He has spontaneous speech with occasional paraphasic errors. He can understand and follow commands. Repetition is severely impaired. Which of the following best explains his speech pattern?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

CONDUCTION APHASIA.
Conduction aphasia comes from lesions of the superior temporal lobe or the inferior parietal region, and is marked by inability to repeat, with relatively preserved speech production (aside from mild paraphasic errors) and preserved speech comprehension. Due to the surrounding anatomical structures, symptoms that often accompany conduction aphasia include apraxia of the left side, right hemiparesis, right sensory loss, or right-sided hemianopsia.

questions.text: A 21-year-old man has a subarachnoid hemorrhage. His GCS is 13. CT angiogram confirms presence of a middle cerebral artery aneurysm with normal sized ventricles. He suddenly becomes comatose (GCS 3) with fixed dilated pupils. What is the single most likely cause of his symptoms.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

 Re rupture.
   Any sudden drop in level of consciousness in a patient with aneurysmal SAH is suggestive of rebleed of aneurysm due to re rupture.
Prescence of normal sized ventricles makes hydrocephalus unlikely.
Hyponatremia does not occur in the acute phase of SAH or cause a fixed dilated pupil.
Similarly, vasospasm occurs 4-14 days after SAH unlikely in acute phase.

questions.text: A 75-year-old man’s wife suddenly noticed his slurring of speech and right arm weakness which completely resolved in 30 minutes. He has a history of diabetes. His blood pressure is normal. Which of the following best represents his ABCD2 score.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

5.

ABCD2 SCORING SYSTEM

questions.text: Sensation tested by following instrument exhibits maximum sensitivity in
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Finger pads.
Two point discrimination is the ability to discern that two nearby objects touching the skin  are truly twopoints,not one.Maximum sensitivity is in lips and finger tips .
Body areas differ both in tactile receptor density and somatosensory cortical representation. Normally, a person should be able to recognize two points separated by 2 to 8 mm on fingertips. On the lips, it is 2 to 4 mm, and on the palms, it is 8 to 12 mm and 30–40 mm on the shins or back (assuming the points are at the same dermatome). The posterior column-medial lemniscus pathway is responsible for carrying information involving fine, discriminative touch. Therefore, two-point discrimination can be impaired by damage to this pathway or to a peripheral nerve.

choices.text: It is a microtubule associated protein.
Functions to assemble and stabilize microtubules.
In Alzheimer’s disease ,it is hypo phosphyrylated.
Progressive supranuclear palsy may represent a tau pathologic process.

questions.text: Tau proteins is characterized by all except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

In Alzheimer’s disease ,it is hypo phosphyrylated
Tau is a microtubule associated protein that assembles & stabilizes microtubules that convey cell organelles,glycoprotein through neuron.A hyperphosphyrylated state of tau impairs its capacity to bind to microtubules.

questions.text: A patient suffering with Alzheimer has great difficulty in completing this task . Which of the following symptom is shown in the image ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Apraxia.
In the image shown patient has great difficulty in wearing a pant which means he may require assistance suggestive of  dressing apraxia.

choices.text: Terminally ill patients taking morphine for analgesia.

questions.text: A 43-year-old female was applying her make up one morning when she noticed the right eye appeared different and the pupil appeared much larger than that in the left eye. A large pupil may be seen in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

lesion in the midbrain.
A lesion in midbrain causes an enlarged pupil.
Horner’s syndrome results from damage to the sympathetic syndrome results from damage to the sympathetic fibers to the pupil and includes miosis .
Opiates cause meiosis. Pontine lesions cause pin point pupils.

choices.text: Herniation of the uncus of the temporal lobe.

questions.text: The following may cause a third nerve palsy:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Herniation of the uncus of the temporal lobe.
Herniation of the uncus through the tentorial hiatus commonly cause third nerve compression due to raised supratentorial pressure.
Idiopathic intracranial hypertension often causes papilledema.
Multiple sclerosis can cause optic neuritis.
Pancoast tumor often infiltrates the lower part of brachial plexus and causes weakness & wasting of the hand in association with Horner’s syndrome.

questions.text: Sensory loss of this pattern would be seen in which of the following disorder.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Syringomyelia.
In the image shown it’s a typical CAPE Like distribution of sensory loss typical of syringomyelia as it commonly affects lower cervical and upper thoracic segments of spinal cord which supply the shoulder region extending into upper limb .
ALS,GBS don’t have sensory loss.
In DM  we have got glove and stocking kind of sensory loss.

choices.text: Loss of pinprick sensation over web space between first and second digits of left foot.
yperreflexia at the left knee jerk.

questions.text: A 46-year-old male has lower back pain radiating down to posterior aspect of his left leg and paresthesia in the lateral aspect of left foot. Strength and bowel functions have been normal.Examination is likely to show which of the following ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Hyporeflexia in the ankle jerk.
History is suggestive of S1 radiculopathy secondary to disc prolapse  in which loss of ankle jerk is an early feature with loss sensation over 4 & 5th web space over the foot. Minimal motor weakness is seen with intact bowel and bladder functions.

questions.text: The following clinical sign would be positive if the lesion is BELOW.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

T10.
Beevor’s sign is characteristic of spinal cord injury between T10 and T12 levels. This occurs when the upper part of the Rectus abdominal  muscle is intact but the lower part is weak because of the spinal injury. Thus when the patient is asked to raise his head as he lies supine on bed, only the upper part of the muscle contracts pulling the umbilicus toward the head.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presented with increasing weakness over his right arm & leg with loss of vibration and joint position sense in the right arm & leg and loss of pin prick in the left arm & leg. Which of the following investigation would be useful to secure the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

MRI of cervical spinal cord.
 The clinical profile of the patient is suggestive of hemi section of spinal cord-Brown Sequard syndrome. In this case it involves arms, so we would need an MRI of the cervical spine.
Nerve conduction study would be helpful in diagnosis of neuropathy which would unlikely cause hemiparesis & differential involvement of sensory loss.
Lumbar puncture would only have a supportive role for finding the etiology like TBM leading to spinal vasculitis.
MRI brain would have been helpful if patient had clinical symptoms suggestive of stroke causing hemiparesis with complete hemisensory on the same side of weakness.

questions.text: Pulmonary wedge pressure corresponds to which of the following pressures?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: Following statements about Sarilumab are true EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Sarilumab did not show success in spondyloarthropathies including AS.

choices.text: Sleep studies have shown disruption in REM sleep
SPECT studies show reduced blood flow to Thalamus

questions.text: Which of the following statement about Fibromyalgia is True:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Fibromyalgia is a pain sensitivity syndrome affecting middle aged females and related to stress. However, MR spectroscopy has revealed a reduced blood flow to the thalamus as the cause of the aches and pains which last for duration > 3 months. Sleep studies reveals disruption of NREM sleep and reduced cortisol response to stress. Treatment is by neuralgic pain stabilisers like Pregabalin, Gabapentin, TCA’s and SSRI’s.

questions.text: A middle-aged female presented with polyarthritis, elevated RF, and ANA levels. Which of the following features will help differentiate between SLE and RA:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Articular erosions on X-ray are pathognomic of erosive arthritis and suggest RA predominant disease.
Earliest radiological feature of RA is Juxta-articular osteopenia, but, this finding is not unique to RA. It is also found in metabolic bone diseases like osteoporosis and Steroid induced osteopenia.

questions.text: A patient of SLE is on maintenance therapy with Hydroxychloroquine. Following test/s are indicated to monitor the ADR of the treatment
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Fundoscopy and ECG
The dreaded ADR of HCQ therapy are Bull’s eye maculopathy and increased risk of Torsade de pointes due to prolonged QT interval.

questions.text: Anifrolumab is approved for the management of moderate to severe SLE. It is a biological agent – monoclonal antibody against the following
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
Anifrolumab is a monoclonal antibody against Interferon type 1 receptor blocking the effects of both Interferon alpha and beta. It is approved for management of moderate to severe SLE on standard regimen.

questions.text: Which autoantibody is most commonly associated with diffuse cutaneous Systemic Sclerosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

 Anti-Scl-70 (anti-topoisomerase I) antibody
Explanation: Anti-Scl-70 (anti-topoisomerase I) antibodies are commonly associated with diffuse cutaneous Systemic Sclerosis. Their presence is linked to more severe disease and a higher risk of pulmonary fibrosis.

questions.text: Following are secondary causes of Sicca syndrome EXCEPT
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

HIV
HIV, Hepatitis B and C can affect the exocrine gland and mimic sicca. Secondary Sicca is caused by other AID affecting the glands – SLE, SSc, MCTD, RA, Primary biliary cirrhosis and autoimmune hepatitis

questions.text: Which of the following is a common clinical feature of Inclusion Body Myositis (IBM)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Asymmetric distal muscle weakness
Explanation: Inclusion Body Myositis (IBM) typically presents with asymmetric distal muscle weakness, particularly affecting the quadriceps and finger flexors. This distinguishes it from other inflammatory myopathies, which usually present with symmetric proximal muscle weakness.

questions.text: The most specific antibody with Dermatomyositis is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Anti-MI2
Anti-MI2 (Muscle Inflammation) is the most specific antibody with Dermatomyositis but lacks sensitivity.

questions.text: Following inflammatory arthritis maybe associated with Anterior uveitis EXCEPT
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

 Rheumatoid Arthritis
RA never causes Uveatis. It is a feature of Spondyloarthropathies.

choices.text: DIP involvement is Early and common
Sacroiliac joint involvement in late cases is typical
HCQ is the most potent DMARD for treatment
Anti-TNF alpha agents are preferred for cases of DMARD failure

questions.text: A 24 year old female presented with inflammatory polyarthritis. Laboratory reveals both RA factor and Anti-CCP antibody positive. ESR is 70. What is true statement about the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

HCQ is the most potent DMARD for treatment
RA is the most common cause of inflammatory polyarthritis. RA Factor is the screening antibody and Anti-CCP is the most specific antibody for RA. Methotrexate is the most potent DMARD for management. Anti-TNF Alpha is preferred for DMARD failure.

questions.text: Which vasculitis syndrome is most commonly associated with asthma and eosinophilia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Churg-Strauss syndrome (Eosinophilic Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis)
Explanation: Churg-Strauss syndrome, also known as Eosinophilic Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis, is characterized by asthma, eosinophilia, and granulomatous inflammation. It primarily affects small to medium-sized vessels.

questions.text: Which autoantibody is commonly associated with Microscopic Polyangiitis (MPA)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Anti-MPO (Myeloperoxidase)
Explanation: Microscopic Polyangiitis (MPA) is commonly associated with anti-MPO (myeloperoxidase) antibodies. These antibodies are part of the ANCA (anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibody) group and are used in the diagnosis of MPA.

choices.text: Skin rash can mimic rash of HSP
Anti-MPO is positive in majority cases

questions.text: A young patient presents with Hemoptysis and dysmorphic hematuria. There is history of sinusitis and conductive deafness in the past. Chest Xray shows multiple cavities. What is true about the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Skin rash can mimic rash of HSP
The case described in the question is Wegener’s granulomatosis. The skin rash, if present, is over the LL and buttocks which can mimic HSP. Majority are Anti-PR3 is positive in majority. Risk of RPGN is more than 70%. Cyclophosphamide is the DOC.

questions.text: The most specific cutaneous feature in Polyarteritis nodosa is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Livedo changes
Livedo changes is most specific cutaneous manifestation of PAN. Raynaud’s phenomenon and Digital gangrene are common but non specific manifestations. Shortening of digits is specific feature of SSc.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female recently diagnosed as a case of rheumatoid arthritis is referred to the rheumatology clinic for ongoing pain in her hands and feet. Which joints are usually spared at the onset of RA?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

DIP involvement is extremely rare and eve if it occurs, it indicates advanced stage of disease. Early DIP involvement suggests Psoriatic arthropathy or in an elderly suggests OA.

questions.text: Following are poor prognostic factors in RA EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Poor Prognostic factors in RA include:
• HLA-DRB1*04/04 genotype
• High serum titres of autoantibodies (e.g. RF and ACPA)
• Extra-articular manifestations
• Large number of involved joints (>10)
• Age onset > 40years
• Female sex
• Delay in initiation of DMARD > 3 months
• Neutropenia (precursor to lymphoma)

questions.text: A 35 years old man presents to you with a 2-month history of pain in his small joints of hands. On examination, nail peeling is noted. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Psoriatic arthritis – Spondyloarthropathy with Skin and Nail changes.
